title: Synthetic Recap
body:
ATLANTA (AP) – In the annals of basketball, some nights belong not to a team, but to one man. Monday night belonged to Steve Smith.

In a breathtaking, virtuoso performance, the Atlanta Hawks’ guard etched his name into the record books, pouring in a career-high 47 points to single-handedly outduel the defending champion Chicago Bulls in a thrilling 108-103 victory.

From the opening tip, Smith was unstoppable. He wasn't just scoring; he was conducting a masterclass in offensive artistry. Every dribble, every cut, every shot was executed with a cold, calculated precision that left the Bulls, a team renowned for its defensive prowess, grasping at air. He sliced through the lane for acrobatic finishes, pulled up with confidence from mid-range, and when Chicago dared him, he buried them from deep, connecting on five three-pointers.

The Bulls, led by the formidable trio of Michael Jordan (28 points), Scottie Pippen (17 points), and a dominant 27-point, 17-rebound effort from Luc Longley, refused to yield. They clawed, they battled, and they threw their championship pedigree at the Hawks. But for every Jordan fadeaway, there was a Smith answer. For every Pippen defensive stop, Smith found another gear.

The game hung in the balance in the final minutes, the tension inside the arena palpable. But Smith, with the weight of the night on his shoulders, was unshakable. He closed out the game with a flurry, scoring Atlanta’s final crucial points from the charity stripe, sealing a victory that was less about a team win and more about a historic individual coronation. On this night, against the mighty Bulls, Steve Smith was simply the best player on the planet.
